What is HIV/AIDS?

HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system which, if untreated, can lead to AIDS. HIV is usually passed on through unprotected sex or sharing of drug injection needles.

            AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) is a disease that forms as a result of untreated HIV. AIDS is the late stage of HIV that occurs when the body’s immune system is badly damaged because of the virus.
            
            From CDC Video
            What is HIV? HIV is a virus that attacks a person's immune system. Most people get HIV through anal or vaginal sex or by sharing needles and other drug injection equipment with a person who has HIV.
            
            How do you get HIV? HIV can also be passed by a pregnant woman to her baby during pregnancy, childbirth,
            or later through breastfeeding. Without treatment, HIV can make a person very sick or even cause death.
            
            Prevention. The only way to know if you have HIV is to get tested. Knowing your status can help you make healthy decisions. To prevent getting HIV take medicine called PrEP if you are at high risk. Always use condoms or clean needles, never share needles, or choose not to have sex or inject drugs.
            
            If you have HIV, get in care and take HIV medicine as prescribed. With the right medical care, you can live a long, healthy life and prevent transmission to others.
            
            For more information on HIV visit cdc.gov/hiv
            
            Learn more about HIV/AIDS
            •	HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system. Having HIV makes a person more likely to get other infections and diseases. HIV is spread by coming in contact with the body fluids (blood, saliva, semen) of someone who has HIV. HIV is most often spread through unprotected sex or the sharing of drug injection needles.
            •	AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) is a disease that forms as a result of untreated HIV. AIDS is the late stage of HIV infection and happens when the body’s immune system is badly damaged by the virus.
            •	To learn more about HIV, visit the CDC website: https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/default.html

How Many Women are Affected by HIV?

In the U.S. in 2019, about 250,000 women were living with HIV
            North Carolina ranks 9th among U.S. states in highest number of new HIV cases in women per year
            1 in 253 women in the United States will get HIV in their lifetime
            In North Carolina in 2020, over 9000 women were living with HIV.

HIV Among Women of Color

Chances of Getting HIV Among Women of Color

            Women of color in the US have a greater chance of getting HIV than white women. The graphic below shows the differences in the chances of getting HIV by race, as well as some likely reasons why there are differences. 
            
            The number of U.S. Women (per 1000) who will get HIV in their lifetime, by race:
            •	Black women – Around 19 per 1000
            •	Hispanic/Latina women – Around 4 per 1000
            •	American Indian/Alaska Native women: Around 3 per 1000
            •	Asian women: Around 1 per 1000
            •	White women: Around 1 per 1000
            
            Why are there such large differences in women’s HIV risk by race?
            Institutionalized racism affects the issues below:
            •	Poverty – Black women experience poverty more than women of other races. Black women in poverty may find it harder to get HIV prevention and care services
            •	Healthcare access issues – Because of racism and poverty, Black women struggle to get access to health care. This leads to more people getting HIV and fewer people getting treated for it.
            •	Incarceration of Black men – Incarceration removes men from their family, leaving behind their partners who lose support. This increases the number of Black men and women in poverty.

How do I know if I'm at risk for HIV?

HIV risk depends on both your own behavior and how many people in your area are living with HIV. It can also depend on how many partners you have and whether they have other sexual partners.

            See previous slides for more information about general risk for women in North Carolina.
            
            To learn more about your individual risk based on sexual activities, please answer the question below.
            
            In the past 6 months, which of the following have been true for you?
            
            •	I had unprotected sex (sex without condoms and/or using PrEP) with someone whose HIV status I did not know
            •	I had unprotected sex with someone who has tested negative for HIV more than a year ago
            •	I had unprotected sex with someone living with HIV who is not taking treatment or not taking it consistently
            •	I was in multiple sexual relationships at the same time
            •	I received money or goods for sex (including food, clothing, shelter, drugs, or other gifts)
            •	I had a bacterial sexually transmitted disease (STD) (syphilis, gonorrhea)
            •	I injected drugs and shared injection drug equipment (such as needles, syringes, or cookers)
            •	None of these apply to me

Why does unprotected sex with someone whose HIV status I do not know put me at risk for HIV?

HIV can enter your body during vaginal sex through the tissues that line your vagina and cervix. You could get HIV if these tissues come in contact with body fluids that are carrying HIV, such as blood, semen, and vaginal and rectal fluids.

            If you do not know your partner's HIV status, they may have HIV that isn't controlled without you knowing.
            
            There are ways to protect yourself from getting HIV from sex. Please keep using this tool to learn more about your options.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
Why does unprotected sex with someone who tested negative for HIV more than a year ago put me at risk for HIV?

HIV can enter your body during vaginal sex through the tissues that line your vagina and cervix. You could get HIV if these tissues come in contact with body fluids that are carrying HIV, such as blood, semen, and vaginal and rectal fluids.

            If your partner got tested for HIV a long time ago, they may have gotten HIV without you knowing. The CDC recommends getting tested at least once per year.
            
            There are ways to protect yourself from getting HIV from sex. Please keep using this tool to learn more about your options.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
Why does having unprotected sex with someone with HIV put me at risk for getting HIV?

HIV can enter your body during vaginal sex through the tissues that line your vagina and cervix. You could get HIV if these tissues come in contact with body fluids that are carrying HIV, such as blood, semen, and vaginal and rectal fluids.

            If your partner has HIV and is not taking their medication correctly, you could get HIV.
            
            There are ways to protect yourself from getting HIV from sex. Please keep using this tool to learn more about your options.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
Why does having multiple sex partners put me at risk for HIV?

HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) are typically passed through “sexual networks.” Sexual networks are formed when the person you're having sex with has sex with other people, and then those people have sex with others, and so on.

            For example, in the picture to the right, Monica and Ella are both living with HIV. While Amber is only having sex with Mark and Tony, Mark and Tony are having sex with other people who are HIV positive (Ella and Monica). Even though Amber is not having sex with anyone living with HIV, she is indirectly at a higher risk of getting HIV because people in her sexual network are living with HIV.
            
            The larger your sexual network is, the more at risk you are for HIV.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
Why does exchanging sex for money or goods put me at risk for HIV?

When you trade money or goods (things like food, clothing, shelter, or drugs) for sex, the person who is giving something typically has more power in the relationship than the person who is getting something in exchange for sex.

            This difference in power can make you and your partner more likely to have unprotected sex, because both of you may not feel like you can ask for things you want or need to feel safe, such as using a condom. Unprotected sex increases the chances of developing HIV, especially for women.
            
            There are ways to protect yourself from getting HIV from sex. Please keep using this tool to learn more about your options.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
Why does having a bacterial STD (such as syphilis and gonorrhea) put me at risk for HIV?

When you develop a sexually transmitted disease (STD), it usually means that you or your sexual partner(s) are doing some things that put you at higher risk for HIV.

            This might mean having unprotected sex, having sex with multiple partners, or trading money or goods for sex (you can go back to the previous slide and select these options if you would like to learn more). An untreated STD can make it easier to develop or pass HIV.
            
            Certain bacterial STDs, such as syphilis and gonorrhea, are more strongly linked to HIV risk, but any recent STD diagnosis may mean that you are at higher risk for HIV.

Why does sharing injection equipment put me at risk for HIV?

Sharing injecting equipment (such as needles, syringes, or cookers) puts you at risk of getting HIV.

            Any use of injecting equipment or needles that have already been used by another person is sharing equipment. If the equipment has small amounts of HIV left in or on it, you may shoot HIV directly into your bloodstream. HIV can live in blood left over in used equipment for up to 42 days.
            
            To lower the chances of getting HIV when injecting drugs, you should use your own equipment (including cookers and syringes) and a fresh, unused needle every time you inject. 
            
            This tool will tell you more about PrEP, which can also help protect you from HIV if you inject drugs.

If you selected none of the above, you have not indicated any sources of HIV risk

However, if you think PrEP or another HIV prevention method may be a good fit for you, talk with your doctor.

            Even if your partner has tested negative for HIV in the past, repeat testing will help you and your partner stay safe. The CDC recommends getting tested at least once per year.
            
            Watch the CDC video to learn more about why HIV testing is important [Transcript]
            The only way to know for sure if you have HIV is to get tested.
            Everyone ages 13 to 64 should get tested for HIV at least once in their lifetime.
            If you have certain risk factors,
            you should get tested more often.
            For example...
            ...if you’ve had more than one sex partner
            or your sex partner has had more than one partner since your last HIV test,
            you should get tested again.
            If you continue to inject drugs and share needles or drug injection equipment,
            you should get tested at least once a year.
            If you’re a sexually active gay or bisexual man,
            you should think about getting tested every 3 to 6 months.
            Testing can be quick and easy.
            Some tests take as little as 20 minutes,
            and some don’t even involve a needle.
            You can also buy a self-test at a drugstore or online.
            To find a testing site near you,
            visit gettested.cdc.gov.

What should I do next?

The good news is there are ways to prevent yourself from getting HIV, including taking PrEP.

Keep using this tool to learn more about PrEP and other HIV prevention methods to see if they're right for you.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
What are my options to lower my chances of getting HIV?

Click which options you'd like to learn more about:

            Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP). PrEP is a daily pill or bimonthly injection for people who are HIV-negative to prevent HIV infection from having sex or injecting drugs. PrEP is available through a doctor’s prescription.
            
            Male condoms (a.k.a external condoms): Worn over the penis during sex. Condoms provide barrier protection.
            
            Female condoms (a.k.a. internal condoms): A thin plastic pouch that is put into the receiving partner’s vagina or anus. Female condoms provide barrier protection.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
Let's Learn about Male (External) Condoms

A male condom is a thin plastic or latex pouch. It is worn over the penis during sex to provide barrier protection. Also known as external condoms.

            Male condoms reduce the chances of getting HIV from sex by about 90-95%. They must be used correctly and for every sexual encounter to be this effective.
            
            What do people like about male condoms?
            •	Male condoms are available at most stores. They are also low cost, easy to carry with you, and can be used with little to no preparation.
            •	Also protect you from pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases (STDs)
            •	You do not need to get a prescription or see a doctor to get male condoms
            •	Condoms have no side effects unless you are allergic to latex
            
            What do people not like about male condoms?
            •	Less effective at preventing HIV if the condom is not used properly. It can take some time to get used to using condoms.
            •	You may not have full control over the use of the male condom.
            •	Male condoms are not a great option if you are trying to get pregnant.
            •	You have to use a new condom every time you have sex.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
How Do I Use a Male Condom?

A male condom is rolled onto an erect penis before sex and taken off after sex. If male condoms are your main protection against HIV, it is safest for the person with a penis to wear the condom for all sexual activity. A condom should be worn for any genital-to-genital contact (such as dry humping) and for oral, vaginal, and anal sex.

            If the condom breaks at any time, stop sex immediately. Pull the penis out of the receiving partner, take the broken condom off the penis, and put a new condom on. You can then safely continue. 
            
            Using a water-based or a silicone-based lubricant with a condom can help keep the condom from tearing. Oil-based lubricants can weaken a condom and cause it to break.
            
            https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/basics/hiv-prevention/condoms.html

What if I Have a Latex Allergy?

Plastic (polyurethane)* or synthetic rubber condoms are good for people with latex allergies.

            Natural membrane (such as lambskin) condoms have small holes in them and don’t block HIV and other STDs. These should not be used for HIV or STD prevention.
            
            *Note: Plastic condoms break more often than latex condoms.
            
            https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/basics/hiv-prevention/condoms.html
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
Let's Learn about Female (Internal) Condoms

A female condom is a thin plastic pouch. It is put inside the woman’s vagina or anus before sex. Also known as internal condoms.

            Female condoms reduce the chances of getting HIV from sex by about 94%. They must be used correctly and for every sexual encounter to be this effective.
            
            What do people like about male condoms?
            •	You do not need to get a prescription or see a doctor to get male condoms.
            •	Some men say that female condoms feel better for them than male condoms.
            •	Also protect you from pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases (STDs).
            •	You can use a female condom even if your partner doesn’t want to wear a male condom. You put it in place yourself and your partner may not notice it.
            •	Female condoms can be found in pharmacies and health departments. They are easy to carry with you, and can be used with little to no preparation.
            •	You can put a female condom in place hours before having sex. This means you can have sex without stopping to first put on the condom.
            
            What do people not like about female condoms?
            •	Female condoms are not a great option if you are trying to get pregnant.
            •	Some people think female condoms are noisy.
            •	Female condoms are less popular and can be harder to find than male condoms.
            •	Less effective at preventing HIV if the condom is not used properly. It can take some time to get used to using condoms.
            •	You have to use a new condom every time you have sex.
            •	There may be a higher risk of developing a urinary tract infection (UTI) if you leave a female condom in place for too long. Do not leave it in place for more than 8 hours.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
How Do I Use a Female Condom?

A female condom is a thin plastic pouch that is put inside the receiving partner’s vagina or anus before sex. Squeeze the thick, inner ring with the closed end into the vagina (this is similar to inserting a tampon). Using your pointer finger, push the inner ring as far it goes until it rests in the cervix. During sex, the penis is put into this pouch. 

            Female condoms are a single-use barrier method that stops you and your partner’s body fluids (such as blood, vaginal fluids, and semen) from coming in contact. Since HIV is only carried in certain body fluids, this barrier lowers your chances of getting HIV.
            
            NOTE: A female condom should never be rolled onto an erect penis. You should not use a female condom at the same time as a male condom. This may make it more likely that one (or both) will break.
            
            https://www.cdc.gov/condomeffectiveness/internal-condom-use.html
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
What if I Have a Latex Allergy?

Female condoms are latex free. They are a good option if you or your partner is allergic or sensitive to latex.
            https://www.plannedparenthood.org/learn/birth-control/internal-condom/what-are-the-advantages-of-internal-condoms

Let's Learn about PrEP

Daily pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a daily pill you can take to prevent getting HIV from having sex or injecting drugs. The name of the pill is Truvada.

            How does PrEP work?
            PrEP protects you from HIV by stopping it from getting into and infecting your cells. It creates “walls” around the specific cells that are attacked by HIV to prevent your body from getting the virus.
            
            Daily oral PrEP reduces the chances of getting HIV from sex by about 99% when taken every day.
            
            PrEP doesn’t work as well when not taken daily as prescribed
            •	The effectiveness of PrEP ranges from 44-99% based on whether or not PrEP was taken every day.
            •	PrEP reduces the chances of getting HIV from injecting drugs by over 70%.
            
            You need a prescription to use PrEP
            Your doctor will do tests including an HIV test and a kidney function test before you start. You will need to see your doctor every three months for as long as you stay on PrEP.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
What do people like about daily oral PrEP?

•	Oral PrEP is safe. No major negative health effects have been identified in people who have taken PrEP for up to 5 years.
            •	You control PrEP use independent of your partner. Your partner doesn’t have to know if you don’t want to tell them.
            •	You can start and stop using PrEP at any time. Talk to your health provider if you would like to do so.
            •	PrEP can be taken by almost anyone who is HIV-negative.
            •	There are programs to help you pay for PrEP and PrEP-related services for free.
            •	PrEP provides HIV protection for both sex and injection drug use.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
What do people not like about daily oral PrEP?

•	You need to take oral PrEP every day for it to be effective. If you struggle with taking daily pills, PrEP might not be for you.
            •	PrEP does not protect against pregnancy or other STDs, just HIV.
            •	PrEP requires a prescription. You will need to go to follow-up appointments with your provider and have blood work done every 3 months.
            •	PrEP’s cost may be higher or lower based on your provider and your health insurance plan or status.
            •	Users of PrEP may experience mild side effects. These may be diarrhea, nausea, headache, fatigue, and stomach pain. If you do experience side effects, they should only last 2-3 weeks.

What else can I do to lower my chances of getting HIV?

Choose less-risky sexual activities like oral sex.
            Abstain from (don't have) sex.
            Test for HIV regularly with your partner.
            Get tested and treated for other STDs.
            If your partner has HIV, ask them to get and stay on HIV treatment.
            If you think you may have been in contact with HIV, talk to your doctor about using post-exposure prophylaxis to prevent an infection.
            This medication can be used to protect yourself immediately after sex if you forget to use a condom or if the condom breaks. It works best when taken in the first 72 hours after unprotected sex.

Question: What are the side effects of PrEP?

Answer: The most common PrEP prescribed to women, Truvada, has few minor side effects including headaches, dizziness, and nausea. These side effects will likely go away in the first few weeks of using PrEP.

            Serious side effects from using PrEP are rare. Tell your doctor if you experience any mood changes, stomach pain, or changes in color or amount of pee.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
Question: What clinical trials were done on PrEP?

Answer: Three large clinical trials on PrEP were done over the span of eight years (2005-2013). The main takeaway of these trials was that most participants had no side effects from starting PrEP. Those who did had minor side effects that didn't last long. 

            A total of 8,390 individuals participated.
            The trials reported that many had no side effects when taking PrEP, and those who did have side effects reported mild nausea, headaches, and dizziness for the first few weeks of using PrEP.
            No serious or long-term side effects of PrEP were found. 
            The Food and Drug Administration approved PrEP for women at risk for HIV in July 2021. 
            Click here to learn more about PrEP Safety/Clinical Trials

Question: What drugs interact with PrEP?

Answer: 

            Drugs that should not be taken with PrEP (Truvada):
            
            •	Adefovir (Hepatitis B treatment, also known as HEPSERA)
            
            If you take any of the following drugs, consult your doctor about using PrEP (Truvada):
            
            •	Feminizing hormones (estrogen)
            •	Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS including diclofenac, ibuprofen, and naproxen)
            •	Hepatitis C treatment medications (Ledipasvir, sofosbuvir, velpatasvir, voxilaprevir) 
            
            
            If the medication(s) you are taking are not listed above and you would like to check for interactions, click here

Question: Should I use PrEP alone or with other HIV prevention methods?

Answer: Using other ways to prevent HIV, such as condoms, with PrEP can lower a person’s chance of getting HIV even more.

            PrEP does not protect against other STDs, such as gonorrhea and chlamydia. Using condoms with PrEP will lower your chances of getting HIV even more, as well as protect you from other STDs.
            
            PrEP works less than 100% if not taken every day. Using another way to prevent HIV in addition to PrEP can help lower the chances of getting HIV even further.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
Question: What happens if I get HIV while I'm taking PrEP?

Answer: It is very unlikely that you will get HIV while taking PrEP. If this does happen, it usually means the PrEP-user did not take the PrEP pill daily-- so PrEP didn't work as well. 

            The drugs in PrEP are made to stop people from catching HIV, but they are not strong enough to control an active case of HIV if you are infected (source).
            
            If you have HIV and begin taking PrEP, PrEP won't fight HIV as it should.
            •	Using PrEP while having HIV may cause a type of the virus that is more resistant to treatment, meaning the treatment medication may not work as well.
            •	Taking PrEP while having HIV can lead to inconclusive or false-negative test results and a longer lag time between getting HIV and getting the treatment needed.
            •	For these reasons, it is very important to get tested every three months for HIV while using PrEP. 
             
            If you are taking PrEP and test positive for HIV, you should speak with your healthcare provider as quickly as possible. Your healthcare provider will confirm the results of your HIV test and help you decide on an appropriate treatment plan.

Question: If I use PrEP, how long do I have to take it?

Answer: You can use PrEP when you need it and - with the help of a health care provider - stop when you don’t need to or want to use it anymore.

            If you stop using PrEP but are still having sex, you should start (or keep) using condoms. Your protection from HIV will lower over 7-10 days after you stop taking PrEP.
            
            If you want to go back on PrEP at a later point, it may take about 20 days for PrEP to start working as well as it should, so you should keep using other ways of protecting yourself from HIV (such as condoms) during the first few weeks of going back on PrEP.
            
            *If you currently use PrEP and would like to stop, talk to your doctor before doing so.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
Question: How much does it cost to use PrEP?

Answer: 

            If you have health insurance:
            
            Medicaid and many commercial insurers will cover PrEP with no out-of-pocket cost to patients. This includes any lab tests and clinic visits needed for PrEP care.
            
            PrEP provider clinics can help you figure out what the cost to you would be. 
            
            If you don’t have health insurance or your insurer does not cover PrEP: 
            
            There are two programs that can help you get PrEP for free:
            
            •	The “Ready, Set, PrEP” program makes prescribed PrEP medication available at no cost. With a clinician’s prescription, patients can enroll on the website at https://www.getyourprep.com/ or by calling toll-free 855-447-8410.
            •	The Gilead Sciences PrEP medication assistance program provides PrEP and HIV testing at no cost to patients whose household income is <500% of the federal poverty level. If your insurance covers PrEP but you have a co-pay, the Gilead co-pay assistance program can help and other co-pay programs are also available. Visit www.gileadadvancingaccess.com or call toll-free 855-330-5479.

Question: If I use PrEP, why should I take it PrEP every day and what happens if I don't?

Answer: For women in particular, it is very important to take PrEP every day for PrEP to prevent HIV like it's supposed to. 

            Missing doses of PrEP can cause PrEP not to work as well, making it more likely that  the person on PrEP may get HIV. If a person gets HIV while on PrEP because they don't take it every day, the drugs used to treat HIV (different from PrEP) may not work as well.
            
             *If you have any concerns about missing doses of PrEP, talk to your doctor.
            
             Learn more about the importance of taking PrEP daily
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
How long does it take for PrEP to start working?

Answer:
            For women having vaginal sex or injecting drugs, PrEP works best at protecting you from HIV at about 21 days of daily use
            PrEP works best at protecting you from HIV for receptive anal sex (bottoming) at about 7 days of daily use.
You are a chatbot that informs people by providing helpful information about HIV.
Question: Is it safe and effective to use PrEP while pregnant or trying to get pregnant?

Answer: Yes, PrEP is safe and effective to use if you are pregnant or if you are trying to get pregnant. 

            If your partner has HIV, using PrEP while trying to get pregnant can help prevent you and your baby from getting HIV. Talk to your doctor for more information on using PrEP while trying to get pregnant.

Question: Is it safe and effective to use PrEP while pregnant or trying to get pregnant?

Answer: Yes, PrEP is safe and effective to use if you are pregnant or if you are trying to get pregnant. 

            If your partner has HIV, using PrEP while trying to get pregnant can help prevent you and your baby from getting HIV. Talk to your doctor for more information on using PrEP while trying to get pregnant.
